I haven't found this to be the case during the last 4 years.

Especially since using Fit/Fitnesse. Each Fitnesse test runs a 'setup' 
fixture for connecting to the DB, if it failed for any reason, the setup 
would fail long before the actual acceptance test itself.

Besides, if I'm changing the 3rd party library or its version, I'd 
re-run all tests to see what failures occurred. If they pass with the 
old library and fail with the new, its a simple job of tracking down 
where the problem is.

ymmv

Andrew



Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> On 8/28/06, Andrew McDonagh <yahoogroups@... 
> <mailto:yahoogroups%40andrewmcdonagh.f2s.com>> wrote:
> >
> > I rely upon Acceptance tests to test this kind of 3rd party integration
> > issues. I find it make my unit tests smaller, easier to write, faster to
> > run, adding a layer of indirection between the application code and its
> > dependencies, etc.
>
> It will probably make your unit tests smaller, but when the bug 
> happens, it
> will take you longer to isolate it because only your acceptance tests will
> fail, and probably in mysterious ways (such as leaking connections).
>
> I prefer for my tests to catch bugs as soon as possible (especially in 
> this
> case, where invoking close() will not make them that much slower).
>
> -- 
> Cédric
> http://testng.org <http://testng.org>
